abstracts.cdata!:
With the collapse of the Soviet Union
            and the subsequent independence of the Kyrgyz Republic in
            1991, the country's agricultural sector experienced a
            serious crisis. Due to a deterioration of organizational
            structures in the state and collective farms, a large
            reduction in subsidies, and shifts in relative prices for
            outputs and inputs, agricultural production declined
            significantly. The rapidly deteriorating irrigation and
            drainage systems further reduced agricultural output.
            Despite the complex situation, irrigated agriculture,
            together with livestock, continued in the 1990s to be a
            major component in the Kyrgyz Republic's economy,
            accounting for 45 percent of GDP on average as well as 43
            percent of employment. The next step was to rehabilitate and
            modernize on-farm irrigation infrastructure within the
            former large farms so that the supplied water could be used
            more efficiently. To ensure adequate maintenance afterwards,
            the government sought to promote the development and
            strengthening of water users associations (WUAs) as the
            critical organization responsible for on-farm irrigation
            operation and maintenance. Support to the government to
            address these sector issues was provided under the On-Farm
            Irrigation Project (Project I), and is being continued under
            the Second On-Farm Irrigation Project (Project II).
